channel.title: The Sydney Morning Herald National Headlines
channel.description: The top National headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit http://www.smh.com.au.

item.title: People's need to flee means the boats will never stop
item.description: It may be a dilemma for the Australian people but, for those seeking asylum, it is life and death.

item.title: Online lessons add up for lecturer
item.description: WITH more than a million YouTube hits, Chris Tisdell is the equivalent of a best-selling author or chart-topping musician. And the unlikely subject of this mass popularity? University mathematics.

item.title: User pays the way for infrastructure
item.description: THE national body overseeing Australia's future needs for roads, rail, ports and bridges says user charges will have a larger part in paying for infrastructure projects.

item.title: Abbott to visit US and China
item.description: THE Opposition Leader, Tony Abbott, is seeking to boost his foreign policy credentials with visits to two of Australia's most important strategic and commercial partners: the US and China.

item.title: US military chief uneasy over defence budget cuts
item.description: THE top US commander in the Pacific has noted defence spending in Australia has slipped below America's European allies and warned that military planning cannot be turned on or off when economies go bad.

item.title: How designer knock-offs destroyed the honesty system
item.description: TIME was, Sunday drivers up from Sydney could drop cash in an ''honesty box'' and help themselves to farm produce from fruit and flowers to eggs and fowl manure all around Mangrove Mountain and Kulnura off the F3 north of Sydney.

item.title: Indonesia calls on Australia to lift refugee intake
item.description: THE Indonesian government is growing impatient with the 10,000 or more asylum seekers using its country as a waiting room, and wants Australia to accept more of them to reduce the numbers.

item.title: Blue collar just won't wear Greens
item.description: Labor's uneasy alliance is shaping for an ugly airing at this weekend's state conference.

item.title: NEWSMAKER DARRELL LEA
item.description: Changing tastes may have been the chocolate maker's downfall.

item.title: Government faces 'mass action' to compensate refugees held at detention centres
item.description: THE federal government faces a wave of costly litigation for compensation over its treatment of refugees in immigration detention centres, including Villawood, as lawyers examine the cases of scores of former inmates.

item.title: Reporter refuses to give up document in Slipper case
item.description: THE News Ltd journalist Steve Lewis says he does not have to hand over a document to the Federal Court because it would reveal the identity of a confidential source.

item.title: Science takes on the man who listens to horses
item.description: SCIENTISTS have challenged the theory behind a popular technique which has been used to train thousands of horses around the world, including those of the Queen.

item.title: Debate on food links ancestral appetites with modern meals
item.description: MICHAEL POLLAN, reluctant food activist and award-winning writer, doesn't see why Australians wouldn't eat kangaroo. Or wallaby.

item.title: Powerbrokers agree to tone down Greens motion for debate
item.description: THE NSW Labor Party is poised to back a motion today allowing officials to give preferences to the Greens last after substantial changes were made to ease concerns among the Left that the move was a ploy to shift the party to the right. But the debate at today's ALP state conference is still expected to be fiery.

item.title: Bowled, Brett: praise for man who kept his pace to the end
item.description: THE Bollywood smile belies the toughness inside Brett Lee that saw him amass 310 Test wickets - the fourth best by an Australian - and 380 one-day international scalps.

item.title: Soldiers face sack over commando training death
item.description: AT LEAST two Australian soldiers are almost certain to be sacked over catastrophic safety failures that contributed to the death of a commando, Mason Edwards, during a live ammunition training exercise in 2009.

item.title: Abbott runs risk of tow-back blowback
item.description: Tony Abbott has been determinedly and deliberately stubborn over his asylum-seeker policy, which includes processing in Nauru and turning boats back when safe to do so.

item.title: It's out with the old as Christian values fall away
item.description: Given the Judeo-Christian origins of our long-held tradition of caring for the frail, census data indicating the demise of Christianity and the ageing of Australia's population could herald a perfect social storm.

item.title: Judd reported as Roos hop into top eight
item.description: North Melbourne climbed into the AFL top eight with a 53-point hammering of Carlton and Blues skipper Chris Judd is set to face match review panel scrutiny.

item.title: Brisbane win bruising battle over Warriors
item.description: Brisbane have beaten the Warriors 10-8 in a grinding NRL clash on a wet Friday night at Suncorp Stadium.

item.title: Barba stars as Bulldogs defeat Eels
item.description: Canterbury have beaten Parramatta 32-12 to secure a seventh successive NRL victory in Friday's clash at ANZ Stadium.

item.title: Scorchers re-sign Gibbs, Beer and Marsh
item.description: South African Herschelle Gibbs will return to Perth this summer hoping he can give the Scorchers a repeat effort of last season's T20 heroics.

item.title: Offshore buyers sweet on Darrell Lea deal
item.description: A number of companies, including several foreign entities, could be sweet on a deal for troubled Aussie chocolate firm Darrell Lea.

item.title: Blair being unfairly targeted, say Tigers
item.description: Tigers coach Tim Sheens says Adam Blair's playing history with the Melbourne Storm may have contributed to his problems with referees.

item.title: Tinkler makes formal bid for Whitehaven
item.description: Nathan Tinkler's private company makes a formal bid for Whitehaven Coal after the close of share market trading on Friday

item.title: Suns won't get priority pick, AFL says
item.description: Gold Coast won't qualify for an extra first-round draft pick in 2012, the AFL says.

item.title: Swans wary of AFL's wounded Eagles
item.description: Sydney coach John Longmire says Eagles ruck duo Dean Cox and Nic Naitanui will be a handful for his defenders when they drift forward.

item.title: Selwood back in AFL for Eagles
item.description: Adam Selwood is back for West Coast ahead of their AFL clash with competition leaders Sydney at Patersons Stadium.

item.title: Kingston doesn't want Panthers captaincy
item.description: Penrith's search for a captain to succeed club legend Luke Lewis has no obvious candidates as stand-in skipper Kevin Kingston says he is not interested.

item.title: Boyd back to his best at Knights: Bennett
item.description: Newcastle coach Wayne Bennett says his side remain buoyant despite their NRL struggles this season.

item.title: Coates big on smaller Aussie Olympic team
item.description: AOC president John Coates says Australia will field a bigger Olympic team than some of its more heavily-populated rivals in the race for London medals.

item.title: Storm's Smith helps Thurston find NRL form
item.description: Melbourne NRL skipper Cameron Smith could come to regret giving advice to North Queensland five-eighth Johnathan Thurston.

item.title: Commodities price boom is over: Ferguson
item.description: Australia can't rely on high commodities prices to prop up its economy, federal Resources Minister Martin Ferguson says, as China continues to slow.

item.title: Brumbies' rugby season on the line: White
item.description: Brumbies coach Jake White says the ACT franchise's season will be for naught if they don't make the Super Rugby finals.

item.title: Lions fight to keep AFL finals hopes alive
item.description: Lions vice-captain Daniel Merrett says Brisbane can wave goodbye to realistic hopes of making the AFL finals if they lose to a surging St Kilda.

item.title: Wes Naiqama signs with Panthers
item.description: Penrith have added Newcastle winger Wes Naiqama to their roster for 2013 with the 29-year-old unwanted by Knights coach Wayne Bennett.

item.title: News Ltd chief ready for regulation fight
item.description: Kim Williams, the head of Rupert Murdoch's Australian newspaper arm, says he is willing to fight media regulation changes in the High Court.

item.title: Marr quits Fairfax on 65th birthday
item.description: Walkley award-winning Fairfax journalist and author David Marr has marked his 65th birthday by leaving the company.

item.title: Pearce's manager denies Roosters exit talk
item.description: The manager of NSW halfback Mitchell Pearce has hosed down speculation he wants an early release from the final year of his Sydney Roosters NRL contract.

item.title: China growth now 'more sustainable'
item.description: Economists believe economic growth in Australia's number one trading partner, China, has now slowed to a more sustainable rate.

item.title: Magpies brace for Cats' best in AFL clash
item.description: Collingwood small forward Jarryd Blair says the rivalry with defending AFL premiers Geelong remains a strong one.

item.title: Seoul's whaling backflip massive relief: minister
item.description: Federal Environment Minister Tony Burke says South Korea's backflip on plans to proceed with "scientific" whaling is a massive relief.

item.title: Seoul's whaling backflip massive relief: minister
item.description: Federal Environment Minister Tony Burke says South Korea's backflip on plans to proceed with "scientific" whaling is a massive relief.

item.title: Cairns a boost for AFL Suns against Tigers
item.description: Gold Coast have a spring in their step returning to Cairns, while Richmond admit they still harbour a few fears after last season's nightmare AFL loss.

item.title: Slipper journalist given court deadline
item.description: Journalist Steve Lewis may have to identify a "confidential" source of information regarding sex harassment claims against parliamentary speaker Peter Slipper.

item.title: Paceman Tait says international days over
item.description: Paceman Shaun Tait says he doesn't expect to play any more international cricket after signing to play for Adelaide Strikers in the Big Bash League.

item.title: Penrith NRL coach speaks out on Lewis exit
item.description: Penrith NRL coach Ivan Cleary says he is still coming to terms with the decision by Luke Lewis to leave the Panthers.

item.title: Australia to host major Malaria summit
item.description: Sydney will be the venue for a major international summit aimed at tackling malaria.

item.title: Reds back Quade's all-round rugby game
item.description: NSW aim to end a seven-match losing streak and the Queensland Reds' Super Rugby title defence with victory at Suncorp Stadium.

item.title: Journalist Denis Warner dies
item.description: Distinguished war correspondent Denis Warner OBE CMG has died at the age of 94.

item.title: Mundine apologises in US for 9/11 remarks
item.description: Australian boxer Anthony Mundine feels better now that he has apologised on American soil for the comments he made in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks.

item.title: Sharpe could give Reds belated rugby gift
item.description: Western Force stalwart Nathan Sharpe says it would be a bonus if his team could beat the Crusaders and allow the Reds to snare a Super Rugby finals berth.

item.title: Bodies found in helicopter wreckage
item.description: A missing helicopter and three crew have been found in Papua New Guinea.

item.title: Port players lucky to avoid axe: AFL coach
item.description: Port coach Matthew Primus says injuries meant he couldn't ring the changes, while Bombers' James Hird is taking a long-term view to his side's injuries.

item.title: User charges needed to pay for more roads
item.description: The national body overlooking Australia's future needs for roads, rail, ports and bridges says user charges will help pay for infrastructure projects.

item.title: Abbott to visit US and China
item.description: Opposition Leader Tony Abbott is leaving on a 10-day tour of the US and China, seeking to boost his foreign policy credentials.

item.title: Energy Watch fined $1.95m over ads
item.description: Energy Watch has been fined $1.95 million after ads which led customers to believe the broker compared prices of all energy retailers when they did not.

item.title: Govt cuts public spending by $13 bln: Wong
item.description: Finance Minister Penny Wong says the federal government has achieved $13 billion worth of savings since coming to power in 2007.

item.title: Magpies' Thomas trains for Cats AFL clash
item.description: Collingwood small forward Jarryd Blair says the rivalry with defending AFL premiers Geelong remains a strong one.

item.title: Payroll disaster may have been worse: govt
item.description: Labor intended to roll out the disastrous Qld Health payroll system across all government departments, the new government says.

item.title: Axed Moloney still wanted by Demons in AFL
item.description: Out-of-form Melbourne veteran Brent Moloney remains part of the Demons' future despite his axing from the AFL side to face Fremantle, says coach Mark Neeld

item.title: Hastings set to take up Pipeline bid
item.description: Energy investor Hastings Diversified looks set to agree to a takeover offer by the consortium Pipeline Partners Australia

item.title: Robinson wants to stay Waratahs captain
item.description: Wallabies prop Benn Robinson has filled in for Rocky Elsom as NSW captain this season but says he wants the responsibility full-time next year.

item.title: Brett Lee has tip for injury-hit Cummins
item.description: Brett Lee forged a brilliant international career despite being heavily injury prone, and he believes emerging Test quick Pat Cummins can do the same.

item.title: Hurley vows to stamp out defence abuse
item.description: Defence force chief David Hurley says any abusive behaviour in the organisation is unacceptable.

item.title: Newman announces new ministerial code
item.description: Queensland Premier Campbell Newman will have a new set of standards for his cabinet after a senior minister Bruce Flegg made a blunder.

item.title: Dulux extends offer period for Alesco
item.description: DuluxGroup has given Alesco Corporation shareholders an extra two weeks to accept its $188.4m takeover offer.

item.title: Seoul's whaling backflip 'massive relief'
item.description: Federal Environment Minister Tony Burke says there is nothing "scientific" about killing and eating whales.

item.title: Origin strikes problems in Bass Strait
item.description: Plans to upgrade a gas platform operated by an Origin Energy joint venture in Bass Strait has hit a snag, with problems installing a compression module.

item.title: Union slams competitive IR laws call
item.description: Union powerbroker Paul Howes says suggestions from the Productivity Commission to review Australia's industrial laws are a "race to the bottom".

item.title: Specialty Fashion in FY sales slide
item.description: Specialty Fashion fears its full year earnings will halve to about $21 million as it struggles with the worst trading conditions in its history.

item.title: Bonds ease on weaker Chinese GDP
item.description: The Australian bond market fell back after the publication of slower Chinese growth data that had been largely expected.

item.title: Aust-Indonesia relations 'dysfunctional'
item.description: Opposition immigration spokesman Scott Morrison says Indonesia should rescue asylum seekers north of Christmas Island, as relations with Australia sour.

item.title: Govt says GST does not apply to carbon tax
item.description: The federal government says laws have been specifically amended to ensure that no GST is payable on the $23-a-tonne carbon tax.

item.title: Stocks to watch at close on Friday
item.description: Stocks of interest on the Australian Securities Exchange at close on Friday

item.title: International markets roundup
item.description: News from the world’s major stock markets

item.title: Commodities markets summary
item.description: Commodities news from around the world

item.title: Wage docking plan to stay: health minister
item.description: The health minister has faced angry howls over his plan to dock the wages of staff overpaid as a result of the Queensland Health payroll debacle.

item.title: We'll come knocking for Kelly killer: cops
item.description: Sydney police are confident they'll catch the killer of Bowral teenager Thomas Kelly, but they say drunkenness is the menace in Kings Cross.

item.title: Aust shares close firmer
item.description: The Australian share market finished higher in response to more sustainble economic growth figures from China.

item.title: $A lower despite benign Chinese data
item.description: The release of relatively benign Chinese growth data failed to push the Australian dollar higher on Friday.

item.title: Gillard on the nose as state leaders face voters
item.description: THE Victorian Labor Leader, Daniel Andrews, has sought to firewall Julia Gillard from a looming Greens victory in next week's Melbourne state byelection, saying it would be wrong to attribute such a result to disenchantment with the federal government.

item.title: Opposition seeks answer on Labor's boat action
item.description: THE opposition is demanding to know why the recent spate of boats that sent distress calls when just off the Indonesian coast had not been returned to Indonesia.

item.title: Protesters step up campaign against nuclear waste dump
item.description: THE Northern Territory government has accused the Commonwealth of exploiting ''political expediency'' by pushing ahead with plans for a nuclear waste dump in the top end.

item.title: Quality courses the key to Asian market, educators told
item.description: AUSTRALIA'S higher education sector has been challenged to focus on quality if it is to regain its position as a major destination for Chinese students.

item.title: Government defends web spy powers
item.description: The Gillard government says data storage is needed to allow agencies to effectively target organised criminals and terrorists.

item.title: I'm best friend of workers: Abbott
item.description: Tony Abbott declares that Australian workers would find he was 'their best friend' - prompting Julia Gillard to retort that 'with friends like that who needs an enemy?'

item.title: Force urges troops to re-enlist after mining civvy riches
item.description: THE Defence Force has to become better at allowing people to return to military service if they step out of uniform for a few years to accrue ''nest eggs'' in boom sectors like mining, the Defence chief has said.

item.title: No place for blind eye to behaviour, says general
item.description: AUSTRALIA'S top general has acknowledged the Defence Force has failed to properly care for victims of abuse, and is urging his members to not ''turn a blind eye'' to abuse in its ranks, following the release of a highly damaging report about 60 years of unreported bastardisation.

item.title: Dark side of the online shopping boom: credit card fraud soars
item.description: ONE IN 15 adults was the victim of credit card fraud over the past year with losses blowing out to a record $278 million as the online shopping boom leads to more Australians being swindled.

item.title: NSW, Victoria post biggest drop in house prices
item.description: House prices fell 2 per cent in the June quarter, and more falls are expected in the coming year, especially in the most populous states of NSW and Victoria, National Australia Bank says.

item.title: Canberra defends data retention plan
item.description: THE Gillard government has defended a plan to force telcos to store internet and phone data of all Australians for up to two years, saying it is needed to allow intelligence and police agencies to effectively target organised criminals and terrorists.

item.title: Labor axes trio in bid to rebuild
item.description: NSW LABOR has suspended three of its most controversial members in an attempt to distance the party from the scandals that engulfed the former state government as it tries to rebuild after last year's election loss.

item.title: Precious pink sparkler lights up museum
item.description: ''IT'S glamorous and pretentious, and billions of years old,'' says the co-director of jeweller Mondial Pink Diamond Atelier, Michael Neuman. ''Everything you want in a diamond.''

item.title: Syrian doctor's pleas for help fell on deaf ears - WikiLeaks
item.description: A DESPERATE plea for asylum by a doctor trying to escape violence and possible execution in Syria and the Australian embassy's bureaucratic response to him are among more than 2 million Syrian emails obtained by WikiLeaks.

item.title: Rampaging price rises to stop, says energy boss
item.description: THE new head of the state's highly profitable power distributors, Vince Graham, has told staff that prices must be held to rises in the overall inflation rate or less.

item.title: ADF to welcome back mine recruits
item.description: The Defence Force has to become better at allowing people to return to military service if they step out of uniform for a few years to accrue ''nest eggs'' in boom sectors such as mining, the Chief of the Defence Force has said.

item.title: Culture barrier to women in science
item.description: Crikey, is Australian science too blokey for women? According to University of Canberra vice-chancellor Professor Stephen Parker, there's possibly ''something in Australian culture'' that seems to discourage young women from studying maths and science.

item.title: Labor tightens focus to find public service savings
item.description: Federal Labor says it has made more than $13 billion in cuts to the public service since it came to power in 2007, and is vowing to find even more savings by focusing on individual agencies.

item.title: Drug dispute may be behind Sydney shooting
item.description: A family of six, including a 13-year-old boy, were asleep when bullets struck a western Sydney home.
